exam_style: Detail-heavy, concept-specific. Emphasize key definitions, processes, and exact terminology.
study_tips: Read lectures carefully. Define key terms (exome, metagenomics, aneuploidy, heteroplasmy, penetrance, expressivity, etc). Watch remedial videos (Bozeman Science). Visualize mitosis/meiosis processes.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about DNA replication is NOT correct?
options: Replication occurs as each base is paired with another exactly like it.
Unwinding of the DNA molecule occurs as hydrogen bonds break.
One old strand is conserved in each new molecule.
questions.answer: Replication occurs as each base is paired with another exactly like it.

questions.question: A threshold trait is one which:
options: Is expressed on a continuous scale such as blood pressure.
Is present in a few discrete classes, but is influenced by both genetics and the environment such as diabetes or schizophrenia.
Is caused by only a single gene, with no environmental influence.
Is present in a very low frequency in the population.
questions.answer: Is present in a few discrete classes, but is influenced by both genetics and the environment such as diabetes or schizophrenia.

questions.question: Thomas's biological mother and father are both gifted athletes. He was adopted by a couple who had no interest in him being involved in sports. Although Thomas likely inherited athletic ability, it was never expressed in his:
Most genes come in alternative forms called:

Ian and Joan are both carriers for two autosomal recessive disorders, PKU (chromosome 12) and cystic fibrosis (CF, chromosome 7). They are expecting a daughter. What is the probability that she will have PKU but not CF?
Gonadal sex is determined:
options: When the presence or absence of the SRY gene determines the formation of testes or ovaries.
When either testosterone or estrogen is produced.
questions.answer: When the presence or absence of the SRY gene determines the formation of testes or ovaries.

questions.question: All genetically normal humans have:
options: Two pairs of 22 autosomes, a Y chromosome, and an X chromosome.

questions.question: Free ear lobes (E) are dominant to attached ear lobes (e). Dimpled chin (D) is dominant to a smooth chin (d). What is the probability that the offspring of the cross EeDd × EEdd will have free ear lobes and a smooth chin?

A woman is phenotypically normal, but her father had the sex-linked recessive condition of red-green colorblindness. If she has children with a man with normal vision, what is the probability that their first child will have normal vision and their second child will be colorblind?
Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG):
options: Promotes the development of the ovary.
Stimulates the formation of the gonads.
Is present in undetectable amounts throughout the pregnancy.
Prevents the expulsion of the embryo.
questions.answer: Prevents the expulsion of the embryo.

questions.question: Epigenetics involves changes in:
options: The base pairing in the DNA helix.

questions.question: If cytosine makes up 22% of the nucleotides in a sample of DNA from an organism, then adenine would make up what percent of the bases?
options: It cannot be determined from the information provided.

questions.question: Number of Barr bodies in an XXXX female is:
The sequence of one strand of DNA is 5′-TCGATC-3′. The sequence of the complementary strand would be:
To produce an individual with Klinefelter syndrome (47, XXY):
options: A nondisjunction event must have occurred during spermatogenesis.
A nondisjunction event must have occurred during oogenesis.
This must have been caused by uniparental disomy.
A nondisjunction event could have occurred during spermatogenesis or oogenesis.
questions.answer: A nondisjunction event could have occurred during spermatogenesis or oogenesis.

questions.question: A man's Y chromosome will generally NOT be identical to that of his:
options: Grandfather on father's side of family.
Great-grandfather on mother's side of family.
questions.answer: Great-grandfather on mother's side of family.

questions.question: You cross two mouse strains heterozygous for four genes AaBbCcDd. What proportion of the total offspring would be heterozygous for all four genes?
A gene showing codominance:
options: Has both alleles independently expressed in the heterozygote.
Has one allele dominant to the other.
Has alleles tightly linked on the same chromosome.
Has alleles expressed at the same time in development.
Has alleles that are recessive to each other.
questions.answer: Has both alleles independently expressed in the heterozygote.

questions.question: X-chromosome inactivation:
options: Normally takes place in males but not females.
Is the cause of the Y chromosome being genetically inactive.
Takes place in humans so that the same X chromosome is inactive in all of the cells of a female.
Occurs in fruit flies but not in mammals.
Results in genetically turning off one of the two X chromosomes in female mammals.
questions.answer: Results in genetically turning off one of the two X chromosomes in female mammals.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about heritability are true?
options: Is a measure of level of gene linkage.
Is a measure of proportion of repeated DNA in an organism.
Is a measure of the level of heterozygotes in a population.
Is a measure of the proportion of variation that is due to genetic causes.
questions.answer: Is a measure of the proportion of variation that is due to genetic causes.

questions.question: Feather color in budgies is determined by two different genes Y and B. YYBB, YyBB, or YYBb is green; yyBB or yyBb is blue; YYbb or Yybb is yellow; and yybb is white. Two blue budgies were crossed. Over the years, they produced 22 offspring, 5 of which were white. What are the most likely genotypes for the two blue budgies?
Single-gene diseases are called Mendelian in honor of:
Why are pea plants ideal for studying heredity?
options: Many varieties with distinguishable traits; easy to grow; self-fertilize
questions.answer: Many varieties with distinguishable traits; easy to grow; self-fertilize

questions.question: In Mendel's monohybrid cross, the F2 ratio for tall:short plants was:
Mendel's law of segregation corresponds to:
options: Separation of homologs in anaphase I
questions.answer: Separation of homologs in anaphase I

questions.question: An organism with two identical alleles is:
In a test cross, an unknown is crossed with:
Autosomal dominant traits:
options: Do not skip generations; equal sexes
questions.answer: Do not skip generations; equal sexes

questions.question: Human body has approximately how many cells?
In metaphase of mitosis, chromosomes align at:
Telomeres shorten after each division; enzyme preventing this is:
Pluripotent stem cells can give rise to:
In dihybrid cross F2 ratio is:
Epistasis: one gene masks another, e.g.:
Linked genes:
options: Inherited together if close on chromosome
questions.answer: Inherited together if close on chromosome

questions.question: SNP occurs every ~___ bp in human genome:
Monohybrid refers to F1 from true-breeding parents differing in:
Prophase I is longest (~90% meiosis time) and features:
Chiasmata visible in prophase I indicate:
Independent assortment produces 2^n gamete combinations. Humans (n=23):
In oogenesis, meiosis II arrests at metaphase until:
Spermatogenesis produces ___ functional spermatids per primary spermatocyte:
Critical period for congenital defects (highest risk):
Heteroplasmy:
options: Different alleles in mitochondria within one cell
questions.answer: Different alleles in mitochondria within one cell

questions.question: Penetrance measures % of individuals with genotype showing:
Compound heterozygote has:
options: Two different recessive mutant alleles at same locus
questions.answer: Two different recessive mutant alleles at same locus

questions.question: Human microbiome: ~___ trillion microbial cells in/on body:
Totipotent cells (e.g., zygote) can differentiate into:
options: All cell types + all embryonic tissues
questions.answer: All cell types + all embryonic tissues

questions.question: iPS cells (induced pluripotent stem cells):
options: Pluripotent cells reprogrammed from somatic cells
questions.answer: Pluripotent cells reprogrammed from somatic cells

questions.question: DNA double helix structure (Watson-Crick):
options: Two antiparallel strands spiraling around axis
questions.answer: Two antiparallel strands spiraling around axis

questions.question: Recombinant chromosomes from crossing over have:
Synapse during prophase I means:
options: Homologous chromosomes pair closely, aligned gene-by-gene
questions.answer: Homologous chromosomes pair closely, aligned gene-by-gene

questions.question: Tetrad in meiosis I is:
options: Group of four chromatids (2 homologs, each with 2 sister chromatids)
questions.answer: Group of four chromatids (2 homologs, each with 2 sister chromatids)

questions.question: Gene pool is:
options: Collection of alleles in a population
questions.answer: Collection of alleles in a population

questions.question: mtDNA features:
options: Circular, 37 genes, no crossing over, mutates fast
questions.answer: Circular, 37 genes, no crossing over, mutates fast

questions.question: Oogenesis vs spermatogenesis: females produce oocytes
options: In utero; arrested at prophase I until ovulation
questions.answer: In utero; arrested at prophase I until ovulation

questions.question: Of 100 secondary oocytes exposed to sperm, ~___ are born alive:
Marfan syndrome (pleiotropy) involves:
options: Fibrillin protein; long limbs, aorta weakness, lens issues
questions.answer: Fibrillin protein; long limbs, aorta weakness, lens issues

questions.question: Familial hypercholesterolemia (incomplete dominance):
options: Heterozygotes: intermediate LDL receptors; homozygotes vary
questions.answer: Heterozygotes: intermediate LDL receptors; homozygotes vary

questions.question: Bombay phenotype (epistasis):
options: H gene controls I gene expression
questions.answer: H gene controls I gene expression

questions.question: Genome editing (CRISPR-like):
options: Making edits, deletions, substitutions in DNA sequences
questions.answer: Making edits, deletions, substitutions in DNA sequences

short_answer.label: Q1a
short_answer.prompt: How many unique gametes can be produced through independent assortment by an individual with genotype AaBbCCDdEE? Provide number only.

short_answer.label: Q1b
short_answer.prompt: A duplicated homologous chromosome pair at the beginning of meiosis contains how many copies of each gene? Provide number only.

short_answer.label: Q1c
short_answer.prompt: Cisplatin is used to treat cancer. It forms chemical bonds with DNA. i) Name parts A and B of DNA. ii) Which parts of DNA does cisplatin bind? iii) Suggest how cisplatin inhibits cancer cell division (max 2 sentences).

short_answer.label: Q2a
short_answer.prompt: A pedigree shows a rare genetic kidney disease. Deduce the inheritance (autosomal recessive, autosomal dominant, or X-linked), stating reasons.

short_answer.label: Q2b
short_answer.prompt: Persons 1 and 2 marry. What is probability their first child has the kidney disease? Show calculations.

short_answer.label: Q2c
short_answer.prompt: Male cats are black or orange; females are black, orange, or calico. If sex-linked: explain phenotypes and write genotypes using B (black) and b (orange).

short_answer.label: Define exome
short_answer.prompt: Define exome and contrast with genome.

short_answer.label: Define metagenomics
short_answer.prompt: Define metagenomics and give example (human microbiome).

short_answer.label: Define aneuploidy
short_answer.prompt: Define aneuploidy and explain meiosis error causing it.

short_answer.label: Meiosis I phases
short_answer.prompt: Describe key events in: prophase I, metaphase I, anaphase I.

short_answer.label: Define heteroplasmy
short_answer.prompt: Define heteroplasmy and explain its effect on phenotype.

short_answer.label: Penetrance vs expressivity
short_answer.prompt: Distinguish penetrance from expressivity with example.

short_answer.label: Mitochondrial inheritance
short_answer.prompt: Explain why mitochondrial traits are maternally inherited only.

short_answer.label: Independent assortment
short_answer.prompt: Explain how Mendel's law of independent assortment relates to meiosis I metaphase alignment.

short_answer.label: Crossing over
short_answer.prompt: Describe crossing over and how it affects linkage and genetic diversity.
